SOURCE: FridaysForFuture; Mitteldeutschen Zeitung; Belltower News; Suddeutsche Zeitung
NOTES: On 18 June 2021, an unknown perpetrator wearing a Ku-Klux-Klan robe shot at a group of five climate activists belonging to the Greens in Seehausen who had earlier attended an info meeting with a prohibited paintball gun. Two activists were reported lightly injured. The perpetrator fled in a car.

SOURCE: Donau Kurier; Redaktionsnetzwerk Deutschland; Fuldaer Zeitung; Suddeutsche Zeitung
NOTES: On 25 June 2021, a Somali immigrant man stabbed several people in the city center of Wurzburg with a knife. Three women died and nine people, mostly women, were seriously injured. The motive has yet to be established. During the knife attack the attacker called 'Allahu Akbar'. According to reports, the Somalian was also suffering from psychological problems for which he had received treatment. The police is investigating the case and the terror attack hypothesis hasn't been ruled out yet.

On 18 September 2021, a man, close to the AfD and allegedly from the 'Querdenken' movement, shot dead a cashier in a gas station in Idar-Oberstein because the employee reminded him of a coronavirus-related measure: the requirement to wear a mask. The perpetrator said to the police that he wanted to 'make a statement' against coronavirus-related measures by committing the murder.

On 2 October 2021, a 29-year-old Afghan man attacked a 58-year-old landscape gardener with a knife, at the corner between Prinzregent street and Guntzel street, in Berlin - Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf (Berlin, Berlin) on motivations police described as partly psychological, partly Islamist. The man reportedly inflicted several neck wounds to the worker, 'disturbed' by the fact that she worked as a woman, causing her life-threatening injuries, before stabbing a 66-year-old man who had rushed to her help in the neck, leaving him serious injuries. He was apprehended by police.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: The Right (Germany); NPD: National Democratic Party of Germany
NOTES: On 23 October 2021, a group of neo-Nazis, including members of The Right and NPD, pushed, shoved, kicked, and threw unidentified projectiles at a journalist filming in Hildesheim. Attackers tried to intimidate the journalist and make him leave the premises.

On 3 December 2021, a Querdenken member killed his 3 children, his wife, and himself in Konigs Wusterhausen (Senzig district) and left a letter explaining that he did it because of coronavirus-related measures such as a compulsory vaccination certificate ('health pass'). He forged one for his wife who has been exposed at her workplace and justified his crimes because he feared arrest and the removal of his children.
On 28 January 2018, early in the morning, two unidentified perpetrators wearing helmets attacked a journalist in Athens, punching him repeatedly. He was transferred to hospital.

On Feb. 26, 2018: Two men believed to be migrants were killed in a fight have been found in an abandoned building outside the town of Alexandroupolis. Autopsies and a search of the area indicated the two died of multiple wounds caused by knives, bottles and being hit by chairs during a fight.

Late April, 2018: Seven refugees, crossing the Evros River were kidnapped by masked men upon their arrival on the Greek side. They were put in a van from which they could not see the road, returned to the river, robbed, and shipped back to Turkey with a rubber boat.

As reported on May 09 2018, 50 migrants were kidnapped and had been held hostage in abandoned buildings east of Thessaloniki six days earlier, although some were more recent arrivals. They were forced to demand money from their families. There were 38 Pakistanis, 10 Bangladeshis and two Sri Lankans, who were in bad physical condition, having been given minimal food and water. One man required hospitalisation for pneumonia and dehydration. Two Pakistani men were arrested for kidnapping and blackmail among other charges. Greek police rescued them on May 9.

On May 16 2018, in Athens, five teenagers violently attacked a Pakistani man knocking him to the ground before starting to kick and punch him to the head. The victim said his attackers' motives were racist. Police is examining video footage to identify the culprits.

On 19 May 2018, the Mayor of Thessaloniki was beaten by a nationalist mob - some of whom were wearing hoods - caught on camera during a ceremony for the commemoration of the Pontic Genocide. 12 people kicked and punched him and threw objects at the mayor, who was rushed to the hospital. The European Commission spokesman, Israel's embassy, the Prime Minister and the country's political parties with the exception of Golden Dawn, condemned the incident. In the following days, all 12 suspects were identified and three were arrested and convicted. The Mayor known for his strong anti-nationalist stance said he was attacked by fascists and that he will not be intimidated.

As reported on May 29 2018 , 22 migrants had been held hostage in a complex of abandoned buildings in the Thessaloniki suburb of Oreokastro and were forced to demand money from their families. Greek police rescued them on May 29. Three foreign nationals, aged 19, 20 and 25, were arrested on suspicion of kidnapping and blackmail, among other charges.

On June 15 2018, two assailants assaulted two Pakistani immigrants and a third immigrant of unknown nationality in the east Attica suburb of Acharnes in a pair of attacks. The assailants stole a mobile phone and cash and beat the immigrants while berating them with racist comments. One suspected extreme nationalist was arrested and police are seeking a second suspect. They will face charges of breaching anti-racism laws.

On June 23 2018, four men assaulted a Pakistani minor in a central park of Thessaloniki on the evening of the day of the Thessaloniki Pride rally and march. The assailants asked him if he was taking part in the Pride event and what his sexual preferences were. The men aged between 16 and 22 have been arrested and they are also investigated in connection to another assault earlier in the day during the Pride march. Two participants - one Greek and another either Italian or Brazilian - were assaulted by four men who verbally abused them before throwing them into the sea. The two men were not injured.

On 13 July, an elderly farmer from Lesbos shot and injured a Syrian refugee teenager on his estate near the Moria camp. The farmer, who was later sentenced to 13 years in prison, claimed he intended to fire warning shots close to the teenager, who was hospitalised with head and leg injuries.

On 16 July 2018, in Santorini [coded to Anafi], unidentified assailants attacked an official of the town planning authority, inflicting facial injuries. According to the mayor of Santorini, the attack was linked to an application for construction in the area.

Early August, 2018: A group of refugees, at least one of which was Tunisian, were detained by Greek police near Orestaida and were taken to a building resembling a military base nearby. Guards of the building violently pushed them against a wall, searched them, and hit them. One of the men used a stun gun on the Tunisian refugee and burned his back. The refugees were detained for one day before they were sent back to turkey.

On Aug. 12, 2018: Greek fishermen reported that they were fired upon by Turkish fishing boats near Kalapodi islet, 300 meters off the coast of Leros island, Phthiotis. The seaman said that the Turkish boats were inside Greece's territorial waters when their crews shot at them.

On Sept. 7, 2018: Two migrant teenagers were returning to the Arsis shelter in Oraiokastro, when they were ambushed by a group of 8-10 hooded men, who demanded to know where the boys were from. They attacked the boys when they replied that they were from Pakistan. One of teenagers ran away, but the other was reportedly beaten with a bat and taken to hospital where he received several stitches.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: SYRIZA: Coalition of the Radical Left; Government of Greece (2015-2019)
NOTES: On 23 September 2018, a governing SYRIZA party lawmaker was hospitalized overnight with non-life-threatening injuries, after a group of 30 people beat him outside a soccer stadium in the town of Kalamata. Greek police arrested eight people on suspicion of involvement in a mob attack by alleged far-rightists.

On Oct. 10, 2018: Three women were found dead near the River Evros, major crossing point for refugees and migrants, trying to get into the EU. Investigation is underway, but Greek media has reported they may have been killed as a punishment by migrant traffickers.

On Nov. 1, 2018: A woman from the Thebes migrant camp was attacked by four other male migrants who attempted to burn her alive. She was hospitalized with severe injuries, while the four attackers suffered knife wounds. The causes of the fight remained unknown.

On Nov. 10, 2018: A 25-year-old Moroccan refugee was caught in Greece near the Turkey border and Greek police handed him over to masked men wearing police uniforms. The man ordered him to take off his clothes and shoes and kicked him to the ground and hit him with a baton, then one of them subjected him to a mock execution. The man was then returned to Turkey.

On Nov. 13, 2018: Four refugees were stopped by police near a gas station in Didymoteicho and placed in a dark car without seats. Masked men took them to the Turkey border on the next evening and hit them with batons. The masked attackers also shouted 'Fuck Islam' and robbed the refugees before releasing them to go back to Turkey.

On 26 November 2018, a former Golden Dawn election representative shot and killed an Albanian land worker in Lefkimmi, South Corfu. The attacker was confirmed to have a swastika tattoo and that he disagreed publicly with the victim about the recent events in South Albania. Police arrested the shooter. The Golden Dawn MP for Corfu claimed that the perpetrator is not an active member of Golden Dawn.

On Dec. 8 2018, a 29-year-old Greek man was caught on a supermarket surveillance camera attacking with a crowbar a Bangladeshi supermarket employee at the parking lot of his workplace in the outskirts of Mytilene in the island of Lesvos (Lesbos) when the latter asked him not to park in the disabled space. The victim suffered a serious arm fracture. The attacker was arrested and set free under restrictive conditions of release.

On Dec. 14 2018, after the Prime Minister's speech in Thessaloniki, a group of four people assaulted a 29-year-old man carrying a Greek flag kicking and beating him in a central street of Thessaloniki when the victim was about to enter his parked car. The young man had previously attended the Prime Minister's speech with other members of Christian Orthodox groups.

On Dec. 18 2018, police arrested a 29-year-old man from Pakistan and are searching for his accomplices for kidnapping 22 migrants - possibly also from Pakistan - and forcing them to demand money from their families. The suspect had already received payment for transferring the migrants from Evros at the Greek border with Turkey to the village of Exochi in Thessaloniki, where he forced them in an abandoned building and asked for 3,000 euros from each migrant.

On Jan. 20 2019, about 20 hooded people in black clothes and fascist symbols carrying clubs attacked a 22 year-old Pakistani migrant beating and chasing him away before attacking four Greek teenagers. The Pakistani man and one of the pupils suffered broken noses and another pupil was kicked in the head and suffered a broken cheek bone affecting his vision. The incident happened at the margins of the rally against the Prespes deal and none of the victims were involved in the protest.

On Jan. 20 2019, three hooded assailants in Patras attacked two motorcyclists returning from the rally in Athens against the Prespes deal and after beating them they removed their mobile phone. It was reported that the motorcyclists were targeted because of their attendance at the rally.

On Jan. 28 2019, according to a complaint by ADEDY, a teacher was assaulted while he was speaking as a representative of the Association of Teachers and Kindergarten Teachers of Samos at a meeting of the Parents Association. The teacher was reading the Teacher Association's views regarding the education of refugee children. ADEDY condemned the attack and said they support teachers in their struggle to educate all children.

On Feb. 1 2019, a group of neo-Nazi party Golden Dawn members riding motorbikes - under the leadership of a Golden Dawn MP and candidate mayor for Athens - that were distributing flyers for a nationalist event at their offices regarding the Imia crisis, assaulted two women in Kypseli in Central Athens, who were distributing anti-fascist flyers.

On Feb. 8 2019, a Greek livestock breeder and another two men beat two Pakistani nationals under the farmer's employ in Larissa when they asked for their salary. They punched and kicked them saying they have friends at the police department and threatened that they would call Golden Dawn to kill all Pakistani nationals in Larissa.

On Feb. 10 2019, in Nikaia, police officers of the emergency team Dias assaulted a 25-year-old migrant from Pakistan because they mistakenly thought he had stolen a car and that he was carrying a gun.

On March 4 2019, a farmer in Lesvos shot two Afghan asylum seekers. There were no injuries. The farmer claims they were stealing his animals and he shot warning shots in the air and the Afghan asylum seekers claim he was shooting directly at them. [coded according to asylum seekers' version].

In March, a young migrant from Pakistan was abducted for ransom in West Achaea and killed. His family reported him missing in late May and on 30 May police discovered his body in a forest area in Boeotia. Three people, all foreign nationals, were arrested for abduction, blackmail and murder.

On 17 March, five hooded men with clubs attacked nine Afghan teenagers playing basketball in an open-air court in Konitsa near the unaccompanied children hosting centre where they are staying. Two of the minors were treated in hospital - one for a broken arm and stitches and the other for acute distress. Later, the police department for racist violence in Ioannina identified four of the five attackers - a local businessman allegedly a Golden Dawn member and three teenagers.

On 18 March, eight Greek nationals with their faces covered attacked a refugee, who works as a translator for the Greek Council for Refugees, and his friend while they were walking in central Athens. The attackers held them down on the pavement and hit them hard on the head and all over their body while they were insulting them. The translator sustained a serious injury on his left arm by a sharp object and his friend was beaten with a metal bar. The Council for Refugees condemned this and all racial attacks and offered its support including legal aid.

On 20 March, police in Athens beat and insulted an asylum-seeker from Guinea who was trying to receive the 90 euros allocated to refugees by UNHCR. The police officers arrested him using excessive force, holding him down on the pavement and kicking his leg on a pre-existing injury from torture and punching him on the face and back. When he requested to go to hospital they said 'Die here, not in hospital' and 'Black go back to your country'.

As reported on 4 April, 16 migrants from Pakistan and Bangladesh had been held hostage in a warehouse at the district of Ionia in Thessaloniki and were forced to demand money from their families. The migration management unit of Greek police in Thessaloniki along with police officers of the OPKE unit for reinstatement of order rescued them on 4 April. A Moldavian, a Pakistani and an Indian national were arrested.

On 6 April 2019, three members of Golden Dawn attacked two photo reporters in Exarchia in Athens-Central Athens. They kicked their legs to make them kneel on the ground while they were insulting them and punched them in the face with ringed fingers. One of the photo reporters believes that him and his colleagues are being targeted for covering the demonstrations against the Prespes Agreement regarding the North Macedonia name dispute and also that this was an organised attack to send a message that Golden Dawn can operate in Exarchia that has a strong anarchist presence.

As reported on 26 April, earlier this week five people - allegedly far-left activists - assaulted a writer, who uses the pseudonym Mr L and whose work has been published in far-right magazines, at a cafe on Botasi Street in Exarchia.

On 26 April, a group of masked men attacked with batons 15 Turkish refugees including a female journalist, as well as a pregnant woman and children, who crossed the border to Greece near Soufli in Evros, and pushed them back to Turkey.

On 16 May, Greek police rescued 11 migrants from Pakistan including at least two minors, who were being held hostage in Xirokrini, Ampelokipoi, in Thessaloniki, and were forced to demand money from their families. It is not known how long the migrants had been held for. Police arrested two Greeks and one Georgian national. The migrants had entered the country through the Greek-Turkish border.

On 18 May, Greek police rescued 74 migrants, who were being held hostage in warehouses in the outskirts of Thessaloniki, and were forced to demand money from their families. It is not known how long the migrants whose nationality has not been revealed had been held for. They had entered the country through the Greek-Turkish border. Police charged four suspects and three accomplices, all of them foreign nationals.

On 19 May, a group of five people attacked a man in Thessaloniki that had just participated at an event commemorating what Greece considers to be the Pontic Genocide. The attackers shouted 'Golden Dawn supporter' before chasing him into a betting office where they stabbed him causing flesh wounds. The man was known for participating at the Prespes Deal demonstrations. Two of the five attackers were arrested. Contrary to some news reports, police denied that the attackers belong to anti-establishment groups.

On 26 May, relatives of a migrant reported his abduction to Thessaloniki police after the men who abducted him and were blackmailing them asked for more ransom money. Police Forces of Komotini in collaboration with the Immigration Bureau of Thessaloniki rescued the man, who was held in Komotini, and in the process discovered a second migrant that had been abducted. Four people of the same nationality as the victim were arrested.

On 26 May 2019, on the day of local and regional elections and elections for the European Parliament, the alternate Mayor of Naxos attacked members of an opposing party while they where distributing fliers near the town hall. One woman was injured and hospitalized.

As reported on 31 May by an Iraqi and two Egyptian migrants to Turkish newspaper Daily Sabah, they were tortured by Greek police when they were arrested with another seven migrants in Didymoteicho. They were held with another 35 irregular migrants and they were all beaten with batons, electroshocked and shot on their bodies with plastic bullets. They had their clothes and money taken. The beatings continued on the Evros boat ride back to Turkey.
On 3 June, a five your old boy from the Koutsochero camp in Larissa was taken to hospital to be treated for signs of rape. Authorities began an investigation.

As reported on 4 June, a Turkish national suspected of migrant smuggling was arrested by the Thessaloniki Police Department Against Human Trafficking for holding an Iraqi woman and her children against their will and repeatedly raping her. He also molested her underage son. He was arrested on 3 June after she notified asylum service employees. The family had paid him to smuggle them into Greece through Turkey.

On 8 June, in the early hours of the morning, two young foreign nationals attacked a group of Greek teens returning from a night out. They first started pushing the youngest one around and then stabbed his friend that came to the rescue in the chest nine times.
On 22 June, a man attacked two members of political party Greek Solution who were distributing fliers in front of their party's offices in Aigaleo, Athens. One of them was injured.
On 12 July, two people attacked a foreign national beating him up in Chania town. They abandoned him bleeding when passers-by started shouting for help. The injured man was taken to hospital.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Units for the Reinstatement of Order
NOTES: On 16 July, under unclear circumstances a homeless man in Exarchia surrounded by MAT riot police was recorded shouting for help and saying he has not done anything. Witnesses including three lawyers claim about 7 riot police officers dragged the man, who was claiming his innocence and was having a seizure, for 100 meters beating him. The police officers' version is that they stopped him for a routine identity check and he attacked them. One police officer was transferred to the hospital. [Coded according to the witnesses' version]

On 22 July, police rescued 19 Bangladeshi and Pakistani undocumented migrants that had been abducted and were being held by a people smuggling gang in a warehouse in Volvi, northern Greece. The gang smuggled the migrants through the Turkish border to Thessaloniki and then held them for ransom. A Pakistani national was arrested.

SOURCE: Ekathimerini; The National Herald; To Vima
NOTES: On 25 August, around midnight Saturday, an Afghan teenager at the cramped Moria refugee camp attacked three of his compatriots with a knife killing one and injuring the other two. It is not known what caused the attack. The juvenile unit, which hosts minors that arrived in Greece unaccompanied, is designed for 160 persons; it currently holds over 600.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Units for the Reinstatement of Order
NOTES: On 29 August, two riot police officers stationed at the archaeological museum near Exarchia assaulted in a homophobic attack a gay couple, one of which is a well-known editor of an LGBT magazine. One of the police officers referred to the couple in a derisive way and when they confronted him, he hit them on the head and the other officer kicked them away at which point they reported the incident to the police and the case will be examined by a Public Prosecutor.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Units for the Reinstatement of Order
NOTES: On 30 August, late Thursday night and early on Friday, riot police raided Vox Cafe known as the informal headquarters of anarchist group Rouvikonas using stun grenades and teargas. One anarchist sustained head injuries.
On 2 September, an Afghan national sustained minor face and hand injuries near the Athens University of Economics and Business when two people on a motorbike rode past and shot him with an air rifle.

On 2 September, Greek police rescued 12 Pakistani migrants who were abducted at an unknown date and being held hostage in a warehouse in Thessaloniki and were forced to demand money from their families, and another 26 from Pakistan and Bangladesh on their way to the warehouse. A Greek and an Albanian national were arrested.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Units for the Reinstatement of Order
NOTES: On 14 September, members of the Solidarity Health Workers reported that MAT riot police fired tear gas into a the street and a cafe in Exarchia after a protest march, causing respiratory problems to local residents and injuring a young woman on the head with the tear gas canister.

On 10 October, a group of assailants using knives, brass knuckles, and metal objects attacked and caused serious injury to six foreign nationals in Aspropyrgos and took their money and mobile phones. During the attack the assailants were swearing and insulting the country of origin of the victims. On 1 December police arrested a young man in connection with this and a subsequent attack on 15 November. [size=no report]

On 14 October, a violent incident erupted in the regional capital of Samos between a group of Afghans and a group of Syrian asylum seekers. Three Syrians were stabbed with sharp objects and were hospitalised. The incident resulted in clashes spreading in the reception centre of Samos, where a fire broke out burning a large part of the camp. There were no injuries. Over the following days, more police was sent to the island and 12 people were arrested. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KKE: Communist Party of Greece; KNE: Communist Youth of Greece
NOTES: On 30 October, a group of hooded assailants attacked a member of KKE and KNE and stabbed him in the arm. [size=no report]

On 6 November, two youths with their faces covered attacked an Iranian refugee high school student, a national of Kuwait, on his way to school in Neapoli of Thessaloniki. The assailants, who are thought not to be pupils at the school and appear to have racist/xenophobic motivations, used a sharp instrument to cut the boy on his hand and threatened him not to return to school.

On 15 November, a young man using brass knuckles and a metal object attacked and injured two foreign nationals in Aspropyrgos. On 1 December, police arrested a young man in connection with this attack and a previous racist attack on 10 October. [size=no report]

On 28 November, a consultant for the Minister of Citizen Protection was beaten and injured by at least two unidentified assailants. A political motive is suspected because there was no robbery or provoking incident involved. [size=at least 2]

On 28 November, it was reported that migrants in Thrace had been subjected to torture, such as cigarette burns, beatings with clubs resulting in multiple fractures and confiscating money and clothes before being pushed back to Turkey by the Greek military. This is the first time reports mention explicitly that such acts were committed by military officers with Greek insignia. [size=no report]

On 31 December, an Afghan national stabbed a young asylum seeker from the Democratic Republic of Congo, who was visiting friends from Congo at the overcrowded Moria camp on the island of Lesvos. He was being treated in the intensive care unit of the island but died on 16 January. According to the Mytilene hospital there are more than 10 people treated for knife wounds from various altercations in Moria.

On 16 January, a young migrant from Yemen was stabbed to death during an altercation at the overcrowded Moria refugee camp on the island of Lesvos. The suspect is said to have stabbed the victim in several parts of his body and then fled the scene. Police arrested a foreign national.
As reported on 20 January, two underage Afghanis stabbed two migrants from Africa in Moria. The attackers were arrested by the police.

SOURCE: Ekathimerini; I Avgi; AMNA; To Vima
NOTES: On 3 February 2020, late at night, about 20 youths that are members of far right groups (some of them identified as Golden Dawn members from their social media accounts) assaulted refugees at a bus stop in Mytilene, where earlier in the day thousands of migrants clashed with police during demonstrations. The following night wearing helmets and holding clubs the same group attacked regulars at a bar in Mytilene where students and NGO employees were gathered. After midnight they were roaming the capital asking locals and foreigners to identify themselves. On 7 February, five Greek nationals, one Bulgarian and one Romanian national were arrested and police confiscated several homemade wooden bats, a metal rod and a full-face hood.

SOURCE: Ekathimerini; To Vima; I Avgi; AMNA
NOTES: On 4 February 2020, 15-70 members of far right groups (some of them identified as Golden Dawn members from their social media accounts) arrived at the village of Moria riding motorcycles and waving Greek flags, blocked the entries to the village and started checking if foreigners, asylum seekers or employees in NGOs lived or worked there. Members of the masked group, which was also active in Mytilene, smashed the car of an Italian national who works for an NGO, while two asylum seekers were onboard. The far right groups continued to patrol the village of Moria and all the way to the camp in the following days with the intent to target migrants until some of them were caught on the act by police. On 7 February, five Greek nationals, one Bulgarian and one Romanian national were arrested and police confiscated several homemade wooden bats, a metal rod and a full-face hood.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Border Guard
NOTES: As reported on 15 February, the previous week a police officer of the border guard had beaten a teenage Afghan refugee boy at a guarding post in Alexandroupoli.

On 2 March 2020, unidentified attackers shot a Syrian refugee in the Evros area [coded to Feres], who later died in a hospital in Edirne, Turkey. The incident, which occurred amid a migrant push to enter Europe at the Greek-Turkish border, became known when video footage of a man shot in the throat, bleeding and being carried by other migrants circulated in social media. Greece categorically denied claims by the Turkish government that Greek security forces have killed three migrants and accused Turkey of a misinformation campaign.

On 4 March 2020, unidentified attackers shot and killed a migrant from Pakistan and injured several from Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan amid a migrant push to enter Europe at the Greek-Turkish border in Kastanies. Turkish authorities claimed Greek border police used rubber and live bullets along with gas, stun and smoke grenades and that one migrant was hit in the chest and killed. Greece accused Turkey of fabricating 'fake news'.

On 7 March, journalists reported that migrants that had successfully crossed the border in Evros were beaten, had their money, phones and documents taken and were returned to the Turkish side of the border stripped to their underwear. One migrant was allegedly shot in the leg by Greek security forces.

On 1 April 2020, a farmer in Chalkeio on the island of Chios was arrested for shooting with his hunting rifle 2 teenage Syrian refugees that entered his greenhouse. The teenagers were injured in the back and legs and were transferred to Chios hospital.

On 22 April 2020, two migrants from Iran and Afghanistan were shot with a hunting rifle while they were walking in the rural area north of the Moria camp on the island of Lesvos. They were hospitalized for injuries that were not life-threatening. A Greek farmer from Lesvos was arrested.

Around 22 May 2020 (as reported), an unidentified group abducted and forcibly deported migrants. Young men mostly from Afghanistan and some from Pakistan, who had reached the camp of Diavata and had not yet applied for asylum because of delays due to the coronavirus pandemic, were tricked into boarding a white van under the pretext of transferring them to apply for legal documents and were violently transferred to the Evros border and were released back to Turkey. DW could not confirm whether Greek authorities were involved.

On 22 May 2020, a Greek civilian was beaten by police officers in Ammoudara beach in Crete [coded to Heraklion] in an alleged racist attack. The man reported that police mistakenly thought that he is Pakistani. In the following months they continued to harass him for reporting the beating.

On 27 July 2020, early in the morning, a hooded assailant shot and injured in the neck and torso a journalist and publisher of a fringe newspaper outside his home in Vrilissia in Athens-North Athens, while he was parking his car. The shooter had two accomplices and they all fled the scene. The journalist was hospitalised in intensive care.

On 29 August 2020, early in the morning, an unidentified shooter targeted VOX, the social space of Rouvikonas in Exarchia square in Athens-Central Athens, firing 8 shots while there were people in the building. There were no casualties. State Intelligence Services have launched an investigation.

On 9 September 2020, there was a racist attack by 3 Albanian nationals against a Palestinian refugee in Heraklion. The 3 men asked the Palestinian refugee where he comes from and when he replied they started beating him and threatened him with a gun. The refugee managed to escape and passers-by called the police. 2 of the 3 men were arrested.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Greece (2019-) Border Guard
SOURCE: I Avgi; AFP; Ekathimerini; AMNA; To Pontiki
NOTES: On 11 December 2020, 3 border guards and a police officer were filmed attacking 2 refugees in Mytilene, on Lesvos island, without apparent reason. They kept beating one of the refugees, even when he was on the ground. The refugees were returning to the camp from a trip to the supermarket. The officers were suspended and an internal investigation was opened. On 12 December, they were charged with assault and with breaking anti-racist laws.

On 13 January 2021, 2 anti-mask advocates refused to wear face masks on the metro train - in accordance with coronavirus regulations - and attacked a metro station manager. Initially, the attackers verbally attacked the station manager, but when he disembarked, followed him to the platform [coded to Athens - Central Athens], where they punched and kicked him repeatedly. He was hospitalized with serious injuries. 2 days later police identified and arrested and charged 2 teenagers and a DIAS police officer for assisting them to evade capture.

On 17 February 2021, the owner of a hotel complex in Grevena attacked and injured the deputy mayor for Culture and Education in the city hall of Grevena because he stated that he would vote against the continuation of the refugee hosting program in the city.

On 19 March 2021, 2 - likely far right assailants - attacked 2 siblings in Argyroupoli, Athens - South Athens, beating one of them, because they were under the false impression that the teenagers were responsible for defacing a mural of the heroes of the Greek War of Independence.

On 9 April 2021 a veteran crime reporter, was shot dead outside his home in Alimos, Athens - South Athens, by 2 attackers riding a small motorcycle with which they escaped. The attackers used a 9mm gun with a silencer and shot the journalist at least five times, first while still on the motorcycle and then closer for the final hit. According to police the execution-style killing of the journalist is linked to organized crime.

Around 15 May 2021, a Georgian man, arrested attempting to return to Georgia by crossing the Evros border with fake documents and accused of the murder of British-Greek Caroline Crouch before her husband confessed that he killed his wife, alleged that he was beaten and tortured for 4 days by Greek police of the Homicide department questioning him at the GADA headquarters in Athens - Central Athens.

Around 15 May 2021 (month of), a group of Muslims attacked an Iranian woman in the Agios Panteleimon neighborhood in Athens - Central Athens and beat her badly. This was reported as part of attacks by Mutaween 'Islamic police,' who go on patrol using folding batons, targeting Muslims who do not follow strict Islamic and Saria law.

On 22 June 2021, a police officer escorting a patient with a mental health condition at a major hospital in Athens - Central Athens attacked her verbally and physically when she tried to stand up after she was sitting in the hospital waiting area for 3 hours. The police officer grabbed the patient by the hair, pushed her down, kicked her, and made her sit down again while slapping her. He was reported and sued by a doctor.

On 8 July 2021, armed police officers with covered faces punched and kicked while also swearing at a group of 11 Turkish and Kurdish prisoners in the courtroom of Korydallos prison during a break in their trial. The prisoners had also applied for political asylum. The incident took place after they refused to be transferred back to their cells during the break in order to talk with their lawyers. An elderly prisoner with heart problems lost consciousness and was transferred to hospital.

On 2 September 2021, Greek police patrolling the northeastern land border with Turkey found a young Syrian migrant with a gunshot wound to the thigh near Thourio. On 24 February 2021, several police officers reportedly beat a prisoners rights activist in Kemerovo while arresting him.

On 6 March 2021, a police officer beat a man he had earlier detained for debts on fines, at a police station in Udarny (Karachay-Cherkessia). The man sustained multiple, moderate-level injuries, as certified by local doctors.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 7 March 2021, 5 unidentified assailants attacked a KPRF MP in Rostov-on-Don, trying to drag him out of his car and breaking his nose. The victim alleges that the attack is staged by the leadership of the regional administration.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) National Guard - Special Purpose Police Unit
NOTES: Around 15 March 2021 (month of), Special Purpose Police Unit (OMON) officers allegedly physically assaulted and beat a political activist while conducting a raid at his home in Khabarovsk, demanding that he provide the PIN-code to his mobile phone. The activist received moderate wounds on his face as a result of the attack.
On 25 March 2021, an under the influence police officer beat a man detained at a police station at an unspecified location in Novosibirsk Oblast. Motives of the attack were unclear.

On 29 March 2021, a police officer and two unidentified men beat a man while detaining him in Dranishniki village near Sertolovo (Leningrad Oblast). A local court later ruled that the detention was not legally justified and sanctioned the police officer.

On 30 March 2021, an unidentified assailant sprayed 2 Navalny HQ activists with zelyonka (triarylmethane antiseptic dye) in Yaroslavl. The activists did not require medical attention as a result of this attack.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 4 April 2021, an inmate at a prison in Irkutsk was allegedly beaten to death by guards, as he was planning to meet his fiancee in the coming days to share information with her on alleged cases of torture and beatings at the prison. According to the victim's fiancee, traces of choking and beatings could be seen on the dead man's body. According to prison authorities, the man died after slipping on a step at the facility and hitting his head.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 12 April 2021, a prisoner from Kabardino-Balkaria was allegedly beaten at a prison in the Republic of Mordovia (Saransk), reportedly after his mother had filed a complaint against another prisoner, who as it was claimed had extorted money from her son.

On 18 April 2021, three unidentified assailants attacked a local environmental activist in Baymak with baseball bats, breaking his legs. The attacked activists alleges that the attack was connected to his opposition to uncontrolled gold mining in Bashkorstan.

On 19 April 2021, a group of police officers allegedly physically assaulted and severely beat a man they had just detained in Nizhny Novgorod, after he hit one of them in an attempt to escape. Police allegedly detained the man for stealing a bottle of hard alcohol in a nearby shop.

On 21 April 2021, police allegedly physically assaulted and beat an SMM editor working for the Navalny HQ while detaining him at his home in Lyubertsy on the outskirts of Moscow, as part of a crackdown on supporters of Russian opposition leader Alexey Navalny, following mass protests in his support on the same day.

On 23 April 2021, unidentified masked individuals abducted and tortured a local Navalny HQ coordinator in Rostov-on-Don. The assailants tried to force the victim to swallow a rubber club and cut her hands when she refused. Later that night the victim was released, with no further injuries reported. It is unknown if the masked assailants were plainclothed police officers, as was initially reported.

On 26 April 2021, 2 unidentified men assaulted and beat up a female supporter of Alexey Navalny in Gelendzhik, who was earlier fined for allegedly organizing the protest in the city on 21 April. She reported numerous injuries, including possibly a broken leg.

On 30 April 2021, police officers from Sharypovo allegedly drove two men arrested for illegal detention of firearms to the outskirts of the city, where according to investigators they beat them and shot at them. Both arrested men were wounded in the incident.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-); Chechen Ethnic Group (Russia)
NOTES: On 15 May 2021, unidentified culprits in civilian clothing speaking Chechen allegedly kidnapped a Chechen LGBT man next to a metro station in Moscow - Eastern and later transferred him to police forces in Chechnya. According to activists of an LGBT support group who publicized this information, police interrogated the man and asked him to provide information about the support group and its members.

Around 15 May 2021 (month of), a police officer detained a man for a traffic violation at an undetermined location in the Republic of Buryatia [coded to Ulan-Ude] and repeatedly beat him, initially while attempting to stop him from running away, but also after, when the man was already under police control.

Around 15 May 2021 (month of), a man related to a member of a local village assembly in Omsk physically assaulted a cameraman working with a film crew for a Russian state-controlled TV channel. The film crew was shooting a report on allegations of child pornography production by the member of the village assembly and by his wife.

On 20 May 2021, police in Voronezh allegedly detained and tortured a local resident who was friends with a local opposition activist, demanding to know the latter's whereabouts. The victim was released after about 4 hours, in addition to being charged with breaking the masking rules.

On 21 May 2021, an unidentified masked assailant attacked a local journalist in the city of Yugorsk, striking him about 10 times in the head. The journalist required medical attention, including 5 stitches. The journalist alleges that the attack is connected to his journalistic activities.

On 21 May 2021, about 10-15 alleged members of Chechen security forces attacked and beat up 3 employees of the nature reserve on the border of Chechnya and Ingushetia near the village of Galashki. The attackers burned down the car and documents of the employees before leaving.
On 28 May 2021, a police officer in Novosibirsk shot a local ethnic Azerbaijani man in the head and killed him, after the man attempted to prevent the officer from arresting a friend of his.

On 6 June 2021, armed men opened fire on participants of an underground concert by a white supremacist band in Moscow - Northern. After the attack started, armed men supporting the white supremacists were called to the scene by concert participants, following which the attackers eventually left the area. No casualties were reported. Police detained 19 people following the event.

On 9 June 2021, 3 men attacked a local journalist in front of his home in Blagoveshchensk, beating him with metal objects. The journalist, who said the attackers told him to cease his investigations, had his wounds seen by doctors but was not hospitalized.

On 11 June 2021, police detained and later beat several women at a shelter for victims of domestic violence in Makhachkala, where they arrived after a lesbian woman from neighboring Chechnya had fled from her family and found refuge there.

On 13 June 2021, in the early hours, two men physically assaulted an underage boy who was returning home with friends in St. Petersburg - Moskovsky, reportedly because of wearing an earring, which the assailants claimed meant the victim belonged to the LGBT community. One of the attackers beat the young boy, while the other reportedly blocked the victim's friends from preventing violence. The boy was seriously injured as a result of the beating, with doctors stating he could lose eyesight. Assailants were detained within two days of the incident on charges of hooliganism, and one of them was placed under arrest.

On 23 June 2021, unidentified assailants allegedly followed a standup comedian and physically assaulted him near Kudrinskaya square in Moscow - Central. The victim linked the attack to a recent joke he made about xenophobic people during a show streamed online.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Prisoners (Russia); OR: The Other Russia; Women (Russia)
NOTES: Around 23 June 2021 (week of), police beat and lightly injured a member of OR: The Other Russia at a police station at an unspecified location in Moscow, allegedly after the woman refused to take off a necklace with a cross during a search. The OR: The Other Russia activist was detained earlier the same day for alleged refusal to obey police orders. [women targeted: political party supporters]
On 30 June 2021, a police officer in Sovetsky town (Mari El) physically assaulted and beat a man at a police station while interrogating him.

On 1 July 2021, a local resident was detained by police in Krasnodar, a few days after an earlier arrest, during which he sent a video to his sister claiming officers were pressuring him into confessing to a crime. The man was found dead following the second arrest, with doctors concluding he had been beaten. The victim's family claim the man was killed in police custody.
On 1 July 2021, a police officer physically assaulted a journalist in Moscow - Central after he started filming the allegedly brutal arrest of a man by the police officer.

On 1 July 2021, unidentified culprits physically assaulted a local man, wounding him with a knife, in front of his home in Berezovka (Tambov oblast, Uvarovskiy district): the previous day, the man attempted to address the Russian president during his annual 'direct line' press conference to ask him to intervene to halt plans to build a new landfill in the area. The victim was taken to a hospital following the incident.
On 4 July 2021, three police officers raped a 17-year-old boy at a police station in Ulan-Ude, by placing an object (allegedly a plastic bottle) into his rectum.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation; Government of Russia (2000-)
NOTES: On 8 July 2021, unidentified culprits in Saratov physically assaulted and beat a member of the local city council from KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation.The victim was a member of the election committee of a KPRF candidate for parliament who withdrew his candidacy following alleged pressure from the speaker of the Russian parliament from the ruling United Russia party, who will be bidding for a seat in the same district.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 11 July 2021, guards at a prison in St. Petersburg - Kalininsky reportedly physically assaulted and beat several prisoners during an unplanned search in their cell. According to prisoners, who were interviewed by collaborators of a local NGO, the search took place after they had opened a window in their cell due to the heat.

On 12 July 2021, a police officer allegedly beat a man in Mostovka (Republic of Buryatia) while detaining him inside a local supermarket for refusing to wear a face mask. According to the victim's wife, who was present at the scene, they were both about to put their masks on when a policeman approached them and informed them they would be fined for not wearing masks. Her husband allegedly questioned the police officer's right to do so, following which he was dragged outside of the supermarket and beaten.

Around 15 July 2021 (month of), two police officers stopped a car in Gelendzhik and allegedly physically assaulted its passengers, two representatives of a construction company. The police officers later took them to a police station and allegedly demanded 1.7 million rubles (approximately 23000 USD), following the payment of which the victims were set free.

Around 15 July 2021 (month of), police in Ulan-Ude allegedly conducted 'violent acts of sexual nature' against a 17-year-old boy, who claimed that police demanded he confess to an offence he did not commit. The boy was hospitalized following the incident.

On 17 July 2021, police allegedly physically assaulted and beat a female journalist in Moscow - Central. According to the victim, the incident occurred after the journalist started filming the detention of a passerby by police.

On 17 July 2021, police in Maykop allegedly beat a local man to death at a police station after arresting him, according to his relatives. Officers themselves denied their responsibility for the man's death.

On 20 July 2021, a police officer reportedly physically assaulted, beat and raped an 18-year-old female prisoner at a police station in Saratov. According to local media reports, the incident could have occurred due to a personal conflict between the victim and a friend of hers, who allegedly would have asked the police officer to 'deal with' the woman.

On 23 July 2021, a police officer physically assaulted and beat a drunk driver at an undetermined location in Voronezh Oblast, having stopped the car after the driver caused a minor road accident. On a video recording of the event, the driver first spits on the police officer and hits him, to which the policeman responds by beating him.

Around 24 July 2021 (week of), a Chechen blogger from Bachi-Yurt, who had recently criticized Chechen authorities for compulsory coronavirus vaccination as well as regarding a minor local issue, was allegedly kidnapped by unidentified culprits representing local authorities. The information was publicized by a self-exiled Chechen blogger.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 26 July 2021 (as reported), a Muslim inmate at a prison in Angarsk reported having been beaten and electrocuted by guards for an unspecified reason.

On 28 July 2021, suspected police officers allegedly abducted a Muslim man at a bus stop in Makhachkala, driving him to an undetermined location where they allegedly beat him and shocked him with electricity, demanding information on a friend of his, who allegedly left to Syria in 2019 to join the Islamic State and later died there. According to the man's testimony, police later inserted a hand grenade and a gun into his backpack, dropped him off in Makhachkala and immediately arrested him for illegal sale of firearms. According to the police, the man was simply detained for illegal sale of firearms.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Prisoners (Russia); Chechen Ethnic Group (Russia); Muslim Group (Russia)
NOTES: On 29 July 2021, six guards at prison nr. 4 in Norilsk allegedly beat an ethnic Chechen prisoner arrested on suspicion of supporting, on social media and in private messages, an armed Islamist group active in the Russian Caucasus region, allegedly to pressure him into admitting to the offense.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Federal Security Service
NOTES: Around 9 August 2021 (as reported), a Russian activist who had earlier been sentenced to prison in the 'Network' ('Set'') case, which leading international human rights groups claim is politically motivated, reported that he had been tortured by Federal Security Service officers while under arrest at the FSB regional headquarters in St. Petersburg - Tsentralny. The former prisoner claimed that officers tied his hands to his legs, pressed their knees against his body and applied electricity to his fingers.

Around 9 August 2021 (as reported), police allegedly beat an underage boy at an undetermined location in the Republic of Buryatia (capital: Ulan-Ude) after detaining him for being outside during curfew hours.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 11 August 2021, security guards tasked with securing an electoral meeting in Novosibirsk organized by a candidate for parliament from the Russian Ecological Party: The Greens allegedly physically assaulted and beat two activists and supporters of KPRF, who attempted to enter the area where the meeting was taking place.
On 11 August 2021, a police officer raped a woman at a police station in Lyublino district in Moscow - South-Eastern, after detaining her for an unspecified cause.

On 13 August 2021, security guards employed by an MP from the ruling ER allegedly physically assaulted and beat an activist of the New People party and his father as they were planning to hold an electoral meeting in Chelyabinsk.

On 20 August 2021, police allegedly physically assaulted and beat one of two prisoners who were being transported to a court for a hearing. The victim claimed the beatings occurred after he asked police to open a window in the car they were traveling in due to the heat. The attack occurred at an unspecified location in the Republic of Chechnya (capital: Grozny).

Around 27 August 2021 (as reported), a human rights activist detained at a prison in Kemerovo was reportedly beaten by guards for an unspecified reason, and was lightly injured as a result of the attack.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 2 September 2021, the warden of prison no.2 on the outskirts of Novoulyanovsk allegedly physically assaulted and beat an inmate for complaining about searches and wrong sizes of prison uniforms, as well addressing him in an overly informal manner.

On 12 September 2021, an underage girl was allegedly beaten by a police officer at a police station in Berdsk, where she had been taken following a complaint filed by her mother and grandmother, who claimed to have asked for police intervention after the girl refused to return home. [women targeted: girls]

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 13 September 2021 (as reported), at least 10 complaints for beatings were filed by inmates at a prison in Angarsk. The beatings occurred after prisoners started a hunger strike following the death of two fellow prisoners, which they considered suspicious.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 17 September 2021, unidentified culprits in Anapa physically assaulted and beat a representative of a candidate to parliament from KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation, who had just filed complaints for alleged violations at a local voting precinct. The assailants also sprayed pepper gas in the victim's eyes.

On 17 September 2021, three assailants physically assaulted a representative of a local independent candidate in elections to the Russian parliament as he arrived to inspect voting at a precinct in Elista. The assailants allegedly also slashed the tyres in the victim's car.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 17 September 2021, unidentified culprits in Anapa physically assaulted and beat an election observer from the opposition KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation, allegedly due to the victim's attempts to report on voting irregularities at a nearby voting precinct. According to local pro-government activists, the attackers were actually supporters of a small communist group in conflict with KPRF, and not representatives of pro-government movements.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 18 September 2021, unidentified culprits physically assaulted and beat an election observer from KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation, outside a voting precinct in Novorossiysk.

On 18 September 2021, an election observer mandated by the ruling ER: United Russia party physically assaulted and beat an election observer mandated by the opposition Yabloko: Russian United Democratic Party, outside a voting precinct in Makhachkala, where both men were tasked with observing voting during the Russian parliamentary elections of September 17-19.

On 19 September 2021, the president of electoral commission (precinct) nr. 49 in Moscow - Central allegedly physically assaulted and beat a female independent election observer, due to a suspected disagreement on the work of the electoral commission. [women targeted: government officials]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation
NOTES: On 19 September 2021, three men in Suvorovskaya (Stavropol Krai) physically assaulted and beat a candidate to the Russian parliament from the opposition KPRF: Communist Party of the Russian Federation and a candidate to a local council of unspecified political affiliation. The attack occurred outside a nearby voting precinct following an intervention in the voting process by the candidates, in which they accused their attackers of voting multiple times at several precincts. According to the victim, attackers were employees of the Predgornyy district administration, and one of the assailants was the deputy of the head of the district.

On 19 September 2021, police physically assaulted a disabled candidate to parliament from Yabloko: Russian United Democratic Party while detaining him, allegedly following an attempt by the candidate to report ballot stuffing at a voting precinct in St. Petersburg - Nevsky.

On 20 September 2021, unidentified culprits at an unspecified location in St. Petersburg physically assaulted a candidate to parliament from Yabloko: Russian United Democratic Party, with the victim claiming the attack was orchestrated by his political opponents.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Prisoners (Russia); Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 20 September 2021 (week of), an alleged member of 'Set' ('The Network'), an opposition movement which Russian authorities accuse of planning attacks against state institutions, was allegedly repeatedly beaten at the hospital of prison nr. 3 in Vladimir for refusing to confess to a murder. The attack was allegedly performed by prisoners collaborating with prison authorities, under the supervision of prison guards.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 20 September 2021 (week of), a female inmate at prison nr. 1 in Blagoveshchensk was allegedly beaten by guards just before her release. According to the victim, the attack occurred after she refused to have her fingerprints taken, as well as due to the fact she was successful in her application to a local court, in which she demanded to be released from custody.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Russia); Yabloko: Russian United Democratic Party
NOTES: On 25 September 2021, four unidentified culprits physically assaulted and beat a journalist and activist for the opposition Yabloko: Russian United Democratic Party. The assailants blocked the victim's car with their own, while both were driving on a highway in Krasnodar, then allegedly pulled the victim out of his car and beat him. Having suffered mild injuries, the Yabloko activist claimed the attack was linked to his political activity.

On 26 September 2021, police beat a supporter of OR: The Other Russia in Yekaterinburg while arresting him and 9 other supporters of the party, following their participation in a peaceful protest denouncing alleged voting fraud at the recent Russian parliamentary elections, which took place in Yekaterinburg on the previous day.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Crimean Tatar Ethnic Group (Ukraine); Hizb ut-Tahrir; Muslim Group (Ukraine)
SOURCE: Human Rights Information Centre; Novoye Vremya Ukraine; Crimean Human Rights Group; Flot 2017
NOTES: Around 29 September 2021 (as reported), Russian law-enforcement forces severely beat a Crimean Tatar and shaved his beard. The victim is suspected of membership in Hizb ut-Tahrir, an Islamic party prohibited in Russia. The incident happened in the Interregional Tuberculosis Hospital No. 19 in Rostov-on-Don.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Prisoners (Russia); Crimean Tatar Ethnic Group (Russia); Muslim Group (Russia)
NOTES: Around 29 September 2021 (as reported), an elderly Crimean Tatar Muslim inmate was allegedly beaten by guards at a prison hospital in Rostov-on-Don for refusing to have his beard cut, which he wished to keep for presumed religious motives.

SOURCE: RBC; BBC News; Lenta.ru; OVD Info
NOTES: On 2 October 2021, a Belarusian journalist was allegedly abducted at an unspecified location in Moscow, by unidentified culprits allegedly linked to the Belarusian government. According to the editor-in-chief of the newspaper the journalist worked for, the victim was detained and taken to a prison in Minsk for writing a critical article about a recent shootout in Minsk during an operation aimed at detaining an opponent to the regime of Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko, in which the opponent as well as a member of Belarusian security services were killed. According to the press secretary of the Russian president, Russian authorities had no information on the circumstances of the journalist's disappearance, and could not send a query to authorities in Minsk on this topic as the victim was a Belarusian citizen. According to a representative of the Belarusian Ministry of Internal Affairs, the journalist was detained in Belarus after attempting to leave the country through Moscow, being forced to return after Russian authorities did not allow for his entry into Russia or for him to continue his trip to a third destination.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) National Guard
NOTES: On 3 October 2021, a group of members of the Ahmat Kadyrov Regiment (a regiment of ethnic Chechens in the Russian National Guard, formally tasked with ensuring the security of the leader of Chechnya), physically attacked and beat two supporters of a soccer club who had come to Grozny to watch a match between their team, Spartak Moscow, and the local team, Ahmat Grozny. According to Chechen authorities and representatives of the Russian soccer First League, the victims were not beaten, but were simply briefly detained after one of the men insulted Allah and made racist comments, presumably about ethnic Chechens. However eyewitnesses confirmed the beating, also claiming that one of the victims was drunk and was simply behaving loudly. Video footage of the event was also published, showing men in coats bearing the inscription 'A. A. Kadyrov Regiment' beating two people at Grozny stadium.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 4 October 2021, police officers detained and allegedly beat a man at a police station in Orenburg and threatened to rape him, in an effort to have him confess to stealing a cell phone, which the victim claimed he did not.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) Special Forces
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) National Guard
NOTES: On 4 October 2021, Russian special forces and National Guard officers severely beat two leaders of the Jehova's Witnesses in Irkutsk while detaining them at their homes. One of the victims was allegedly beaten for refusing to unblock his cell phone to show the content of his messages. The Jehovah's Witnesses are legally banned in Russia following a decision by the Russian Supreme Court, which designated the organization as 'extremist' in 2017. However, the religious group continues to operate unofficially.

On 4 October 2021, several police officers allegedly beat a man they had earlier detained, at a police station in Tbilisskaya, Krasnodar Krai. According to the victim, his assailants were trying to have him confess to a case of theft. The victim died of his wounds a few weeks after the attack.

On 11 October 2021, police in Essentuki beat a man who they had just detained for protesting near a court, where protests are illegal by Russian law (the man claimed he was standing at a sufficient distance from the court building and that his actions were legal). According to the victim, who was demonstrating in support of Russian opposition leader Alexey Navalny, he was punched by a police officer, briefly fainted, and suffered partial loss of eyesight as a result of the incident.
Around 17 October 2021, police in Novorossiysk allegedly severely beat a man for an unspecified reason.

On 24 October 2021, police allegedly used bats and tasers against dozens of fans of the Moscow Spartak soccer club at the Zenit stadium in St. Petersburg - Petrogradsky, while the fans were attempting to leave the stadium at mid-time, supposedly due to their team's very low performance during the match. Stadium gates remained closed, due to which Spartak fans could not leave. Following this some of them started loudly protesting against the situation, with police reacting by using physical force against the victims.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 25 October 2021 (week of), a prisoner was severely beaten by guards at prison nr. 1 in Volgograd. According to prison authorities, the man committed suicide on 28 October, with the victim's family claiming marks from severe beating could be seen on his body.

On 30 October 2021, an environmental activist in Zheleznovodsk was beaten by police at a local police station, where he was taken and arrested for 24 hours on charges of being in a public space under the influence of alcohol and of disrupting public order.

On 7 November 2021, police beat an OR: The Other Russia activist at a police station in Perm, after detaining him at a two-person protest in the city, at which participants demanded a reform of the Russian penitentiary service, in light of recent revelations on cases of torture in Russian prisons.

On 17 November 2021, police physically assaulted and beat a journalist who was filming a corridor in the Moscow Oblast court in Krasnogorsk, where he had come for a hearing in the case of two colleagues of his. Police suffocated the man in an attempt to make him fall to the ground. The victim was hospitalized with a concussion as a result of the incident.
Around 24 November 2021 (as reported), a police officer beat two men whose car he had pulled over at the entry to Magas city, for an unspecified reason. One of the victims was underage.

Around 24 November 2021 (as reported), a group of 4 men led by a former regional councilor of unspecified political affiliation beat an environmental activist on a village road in Novokuznetsk district: according to the victim, the former councilor participated in the beating, which the man said was linked to his environmental activism. The former councilor claimed he was a witness of the event, but did not participate in the violence.

On 25 November 2021, a professional wrestler beat a local blogger in Dagestanskiye Ogni, in what the victim claimed was an attack on him ordered by local authorities after he publicized a case of municipal land in the area being sold at below-market value.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: LDPR: Liberal Democratic Party of Russia; Government of Russia (2000-)
NOTES: On 26 November 2021, unidentified culprits attacked and beat a member of the Khabarovsk Oblast legislative council, on a street in Khabarovsk. The politician is formally still a member of LDPR: Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, however due to disagreements with party management he had earlier left the LDPR faction in the legislative council. A colleague of the victim, himself a Russian senator, claimed the attack was politically motivated, as the culprits did not steal any of the victim's valuables. Moreover, the attack occurred days before a vote at the legislative council: the victim was known for his support of the former governor of Khabarovsk Oblast, Sergei Furgal, whose arrest in summer 2019 provoked months of mass protests in the city, as supporters of the former governor claimed the charges against Furgal (organizing murders in the early 2000s), were politically motivated.

On 26 November 2021, police officers beat and tasered a man they had just detained, in an attempt to have the victim admit to a case of theft. The attack occurred while the man was being transported in a police car from Lesosibirsk to Kansk.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Around 26 November 2021 (as reported), prison guards beat an inmate at prison nr. 6 on the outskirts of Omutninsk, right after a visit by human rights defenders and a journalist from Moscow, who came to the facility to investigate claims of irregularities and violence against prisoners.

On 26 November 2021, police beat a former aid to the minister of labor of the Republic of Ingushetia, at his home at an undetermined location in Ingushetia, with the victim claiming the violence was caused by his revelations of irregularities in an investigation into corruption involving local officials. [coded to Magas]

On 29 November 2021, a man who attempted to enter a shopping mall in Kazan attacked a security guard at the mall with a knife after being asked to present a coronavirus vaccination certificate. The victim sustained injuries to his hand as a result of the attack.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) Special Forces
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) National Guard - Special Purpose Police Unit (OMON)
NOTES: On 3 December 2021, special forces and special purpose police units of the Russian National Guard (OMON) assaulted and beat approximately 150 inmates at prison nr 27 in Volchanets, severely wounding 16 of them. One of the prisoners, an ethnic Chechen man, died the following day as a result of the wounds he sustained. According to prison authorities, the security forces' intervention was meant to curb 'extremist activity' by inmates, in particular membership in informal organizations of prisoners directly questioning prison authorities.

On 7 December 2021, a former Russian soldier entered the Ryazansky public services provision center in Moscow - South-Eastern and opened fire on people gathered inside, near the building's entrance, killing two (a security guard and an employee) and seriously injuring four people. The man opened fire after being demanded to put on a face mask, which is mandatory in the center due to coronavirus restrictions: eyewitnesses of the event, as well as the man himself, cited this as the reason for the shooting. However, according to police officials, the attack was caused by a material disagreement, and was not related to coronavirus restrictions.

On February 16, 2018 in Karaburma, Belgrade, two reporters from the 'O2' and 'Prva televizija' media outlets respectively were assaulted while reporting on a story about illegal migrants found in a private house in that settlement.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CRTA: Centre for Research, Transparency, and Accountability
NOTES: On March 4, 2018 during the local elections for Belgrade City Council in Serbia one of the observers of the CRTA NGO was attacked in the municipality of New Belgrade.
On March 4, 2018 during the local elections for Belgrade City Council in Serbia one of the activists of the Serbian Progressive Party was attacked in the municipality of Vozdovac.
On March 25, 2018 in Novi Pazar, Serbia, a Muslim religious leader was attacked by unknown armed perpetrators, which left him suffering life-threatening injuries.
On April 17, 2018 in Leskovac, Serbia TV Prva journalist team was assaulted, during which a cameraman suffered a head injury.
On July 10, 2018 in Bela Crkva, Serbia journalist Stefan Cvetkovic was assaulted with a metal pipe.

On July 28, 2018 in Belgrade, Serbia lawyer Dragoslav Ognjanovic was shot. Ognjanovic was known for having represented late Serbian dictator Slobodan Milosevic. His death provoked a lawyer strike with lawyers demanding greater protection from the state.
On September 22, 2018 in Sabac, Serbia, activist of SNS political party reported a politically motivated assault on his wife by unknown perpetrators, who threatened her with the safety of her family.

On October 7, 2018, two young Kosovo Albanian men were attacked in Novi, Sad, Serbia, allegedly because of their ethnicity. According to the reports, one is still in hospital, struggling for his life. Four persons were arrested and the investigation is still ongoing.
On November 23, 2018 in Krusevac, Serbia the leader and founder of Levica Srbije (Serbian Left) Borko Stefanovic and two activists of the Serbian left were assaulted by unknown perpetrators.
On January 31, 2019 in Valjevo, Serbia unknown perpetrators attacked a journalist Marko Acimovic while he was reporting about a public gathering happening at that moment.
